and by Finns elsewhere, predominantly in Scandinavia.  Whether travellers to Finland

to learn Finnish is doubtful, since most Finns — including virtually all under 40 – speak at least some English.  However, since so few people make the effort, you're guaranteed to get delighted reactions if you try.

value: Blue = spoken by the majority, green=spoken by a (sizable) minority

and hence completely unrelated to almost every language between Iceland and India.  In particular, Finnish has grammatically nothing at all in common with other Scandinavian languages or Russian. Although there are many loan words especially from

, they are not necessarily recognizable due to the very different phonology. The use of modern neologisms instead of borrowing is common, but there may be a less used loan word in addition to the neologism.

The origin of these languages traces back over 5000 years to nomadic peoples of the Ural mountains in Russia that migrated westward into Europe. Just across the Gulf of Finland the closest modern relative to the Finnish language,
, is spoken. Other related languages are the Sámi languages of Lapland and the Murmansk Peninsula, and more distantly,

.

Finnish is an agglunatively language, and suffixes express what English expresses mostly with prepositions. For instance,

The Finnish language is fairly easy to pronounce: it has one of the most phonetic writing systems in the world, with only a small number of simple consonants and relatively few vowel sounds.

Native English speakers tend to have the most problems with
make the same distiction – consider the "a" sounds of
(front), or the difference in the "i" sound for

(long) – but you will need to pay extra attention to it in Finnish.

In Finnish, all vowels are single sounds (or "pure" vowels). Doubled letters are simply pronounced longer, but it's important to differentiate between short and long sounds. Example:

:
(is heard) shown in this phrasebook contrasts with

(expense).

The basic Finnish alphabet consists of the following letters:

value: Finnish has an unusual feature called

, which means that the front vowels (ä, ö, y) and the back vowels (a, o, u) can never be found in the same word.  (Compound words don't count, and the mid-vowels i, e are OK anywhere.)  This extends even into loanwords and conjugations: most Finns pronounce Olympia as
, and suffixes with "a" bend into "ä" when necessary (

Long vowels are indicated simply by doubling the vowel in question.

, it should be pronounced lengthened.  For plosives like p, t, k, this means getting your mouth ready to say it, but pausing for a moment.  Hence

on the first syllable and is usually weak; compounds words have more than one stressed syllable. Don't confuse stress with vowel length; they occur independently in Finnish. There is

in Finnish speech, just a long strings of fairly monotone sounds, with all syllables given equal value except the first one.  Foreigners tend to think this makes the language sound rather depressing; Finns, on the other hand, wonder why everybody else's languages—including Russian—sound so sing-songy.

Finnish grammar is radically different from English (or any other Indo-European language), making Finnish a rather difficult language to master, and Finns love to regale foreigners with horror stories of compound words a mile long and verbs with seventeen suffixes tacked on.  Basically,

in a sentence (nouns, verbs, adjectives, pronouns) inflects to indicate who is doing what, why, when and in what way, so constructing even a simple sentence requires lots of tweaking about:

: I go to the shop.  I quickly buy bread.
:

.

Nouns can be declined in 14 different cases and there is a whole assortment of additional suffixes, leading to improbable but entirely grammatical monsters like

("even by using his non-fisherman-likeness").

The good news is that most of these monstrosities are limited to formal written Finnish, and it's possible to "speak like Tarzan" (without conjugating anything) in subject-verb-object order like English and still be more or less understood.

value: Minä mennä kauppa, minä nopea ostaa leipä

(I go shop, I quick buy bread) will get you a zero in Finnish class, but it gets the message across.

And there are some minor consolations for the aspiring student: Finnish has no articles and no grammatical gender. Rules for conjugation are often complex, but at least they are very regular.

Phrases in the following phrase list use the informal singular (
), which is by far the most common form in modern Finnish and appropriate for almost all situations a traveller might encounter.
Due to the ease, specificity and regularity of Finnish pronunciation, the difficulty of transcribing long vowels, and the general inaccuracy of English-based phoneticizations,

value: it is highly recommended you take a few minutes to learn the alphabet instead of relying on the phoneticizations

.  That being said, however, Finns are often quite excited to hear a foreigner attempt to speak the language and tend to be very forgiving of pronunciation blunders.

) (NOTE: this is not used merely as a conversational phrase as in English. Expect a longer story in response if you say this!)

value: for "78" seem terribly long-winded?  Finns think so too, and in colloquial speech they abbreviate brutally, leaving just the first syllable of each component:
.  Here are the short "prefix" forms, but note that they can

be used in compounds.
; 1 : yks-
; 2 : kaks-
; 3 : kol-
; 4 : nel-
; 5 : viis-
; 6 : kuus-
; 7 : seit-
; 8 : kaheks-
; 9 : yheks-
; 10 : -kyt

can occur on badly localized computerized displays and similar, but usually the point is used to separate groups of three digits:

; a million : 1.000.000
; one euro : 1,–

In the spoken language the 12-hour clock is more common, with AM/PM specified informally where necessary (no fixed words). The 24-hour clock can be used also then (and does not rely on your understanding of which "seven o'clock" is meant), and it is used almost exclusively in tables, for opening hours and the like.

; one o'clock AM : kello yksi (yöllä)

kahdelta
; at noon : kello kaksitoista, keskipäivällä

kahdeltatoista (the "teens" have their inflection before "toista", "of the second")

Minutes and fractions:
; twenty past (one) : kaksikymmentä yli (yksi/yhden)
; five to (two) : viisi vaille (kaksi)
; a quarter to (three) : varttia vaille (kolme)
; a quarter past (four) : vartin yli (neljä)
; half past (one) : puoli kaksi (sic!)
Dates are written in the day-month-year order, eg. 2.5.1990 for May 2nd, 1990.  If the month is written out, both the forms
Due to the difficulty of conjugating various place names, the phrases below are not grammatically correct.  They will, however, definitely be understood.
In general, the name of the language is the same as the country, but uncapitalized.
; How much is a ticket to _____? : Paljonko maksaa lippu _____in? (

)
; One ticket to _____, please. : Yksi lippu _____in, kiitos. (

)
; Where is the train/bus to _____? : Missä on _____n juna/bussi? (

)
; Does this train/bus stop in _____? : Pysähtyykö tämä juna/bussi _____ssa? (

)
; When does the train/bus for _____ leave? : Milloin _____n juna/bussi lähtee? (

)
; When will this train/bus arrive in _____? : Milloin tämä juna/bussi saapuu _____in? (

Replace 'i' in '-in' with the preceding vowel, as in Vaasa - Vaasaan. Exceptions where '-lle' is used instead are rife and irregular, for instance
. Places that take their name from a lake, river, rapids, or other waterway (

value: Ylöjärvi - Ylöjärvelle, Seinäjoki - Seinäjoelle, Äänekoski - Äänekoskelle

. Using the wrong form can sound funny (e.g. when meaning literally going into the body of water), but will usually easily be understood. Other exceptions may sometimes make your sentence more confusing (Tarzan speak can help if you get stuck).
; How do I get to _____ ? : Miten pääsen _____lle/in* ? (

value: Generally, -lle is used for open places while -in is used for houses and other indoor locations, but this is irregular, e.g. -lle having a more abstract meaning.
